title: Will India sign either of the two remaining defense foundational agreements with the U.S. before 2018?
preds: I doubt anything will happen in the next week.

US is still trying to convince India to sign. Success does not sound imminent. http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/world/full-transfer-of-tech-in-defence-aviation-in-non-negotiable-us-india-strategic-partnership-forum-official/article9968794.ece
Trump administration is not pursuing the foundational agreements, which have met with too much resistance from India.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-india-tillerson/u-s-wants-stronger-india-economic-defense-ties-given-chinas-rise-tillerson-idUSKBN1CN31Z
This story almost induced me to increase the odds on India's signing something, but (a) nobody thinks Tillerson speaks for the United States any more, and (b) nobody thinks the US will remain faithful to any agreement it signs any more.  Staying at 100% No; I wish I thought this a mistake.

The Pentagon instead of the foundational agreements is now looking for some India specific documentation that would provide institutional mechanisms, address India’s concerns and meet the Congressional-mandated legislative requirements in this regard. This could be seen as a major climbdown, as India had been resisting from signing any foundational agreements for the past several years because of sovereignty concerns. 
http://www.livemint.com/Politics/X2Npko3cV6W08IplGpTpNI/James-Mattis-visit-aimed-at-taking-IndiaUS-defence-ties-to.html USA 0 Bharat 1
There still isn't a time-frame to sign either agreement.
Doklam seems to be settling down. Not much of a trigger in the short term without it.

China is raising the Doklam tensions rather than working to defuse them.
Probably should drop to 80% from 85%. I really don't know how to analyse this issue further since it requires a deep understanding regarding potential impact on India's perennially friendly relations with Russia.

http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/07/china-demands-india-pulls-troops-border-dispute-170724065132611.html
The more or less perennial game of chicken goes on, but probably not interesting or different enough to get India to sign agreements with a country that is addicted to redefining or repudiating its agreements.

Going down to 85% from 92% due to the recent stand-off with China at Doklam. Both parties are not budging. I would have been more confident about the signing had the US been keen to repair its relations with Russia, which seems unlikely as things stand.

1.It has nearly been a year since India and the United States signed a landmark agreement to share military logistics that gives access to each other’s facilities for supply and repair of defence assets. However, even at the biggest military drill between the two nations, in the Bay of Bengal, the Logistics Exchange Memorandum of Agreement (LEMOA) has not been operationalised.
https://theprint.in/2017/07/17/logistics-pact-signed-over-a-year-ago-couldnt-be-utilised-at-malabar/ 2. It took over 10 years to get an uncontroversial agreement passed. The other two will likely never be signed at any date in the future.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-india-usa-idUSKBN19H0EK President LIttlefingers' office says that he and Modi have much in common on account of both being active Twits.  Modi will kiss Trump on all four cheeks and agree to sign up for at least one of these agreements, presumably whichever one puts India less at risk when the US goes off the rails again.  Trump will have no idea what Modi is talking about but will proclaim a great victory for his cuddly negotiating style.  Twits will abound.   I'll be coming back down again if nothing happens by, say, Wednesday or Thursday.   Since nothing has been happening with dizzying regularity for several months now, this is still the most probable outcome.

"It will be helpful if India and US are able to sign all three foundational agreements otherwise it makes things more challenging. So the overall feeling is progress should be made in the foundational pacts,” said Benjamin Schwartz, Director for Aerospace and Defense, US-India Business Council (USIBC)"  Meeting june 26th US main exporter of Indian goods and this %age has grown substantially in past fifteen years US main destination for tech workers and reduction in US H-1B visas India needs US clout against Pakistan

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-pakistan-exclusive-idUSKBN19B0C8
If I were India and saw this, I might see now as a propitious time to sign things, no matter how meaningless the US might render them later.  Probably come down on this after I come to my senses, though.

LSA (Logistics Support Agreement) 
CISMOA (Communication Interoperability and Security Memorandum Agreement)
BECA (Basic Exchange and Cooperation Agreement) They are "foundational agreements" which are routine instruments used by the US for geospatial intelligence to promote military cooperation with partner-countries. These agreements are foundational but are not the prerequisites for holding bilateral cooperation with US.  CISMOA, would allow the United States to supply India with its proprietary encrypted communications equipment and systems, allowing secure peacetime and wartime communication between high-level military leaders on both sides. CISMOA would extend this capability to Indian and U.S. military assets, including aircraft and ships. BECA would set a framework through which the United States could share sensitive data to aid targeting and navigation with India. India has been resisting to sign these agreements and the resistance is more political than military based:
a) apprehensions like India would lose its military neutrality stand; b) Russia's concern on increasing Indian and US military cooperation especially after the formation of DTTI (Defence Technology and Trade Initiative), a body to remove obstacles to release the technology to India; c) apprehensions regarding India and China relationship which could be affected due to China's visualization of US activity with any South Asian nation as its 'Asia Pivot' Strategy. Other countries who have signed these tri-agreements like France, Germany, Srilanka are still able to have good relations with other countries including economic and military agreements. China is still investing in infrastructure in Srilanka.
_____________________________
COMMENT: All the news I could find were rather old and said that India is in no hurry to sign them.

Unlikely since Trump administration does not appear to be in a hurry to meet with Modi. He is due to for a visit in Washington shortly, but I would be surprised if these agreements get finalized because of that.
Signing a deal with the Trump government is like a lucky bag. You don't really know what you get.
Signing agreements with the US just now strikes me as very much like agreeing to live inside a pinball machine, in case anybody remembers those....

India doesn't seem to be in any hurry to sign these agreements. http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/india-will-eventually-ink-other-agreements-pushed-by-us-manohar-parrikar-3003315/

The much-ballyhooed logistics pact between India and the US, which will allow reciprocal access to each other's military bases for refuelling, repair and maintenance of warships and aircraft, is yet to enter into force despite being inked seven months ago. Slow decision-making, bureaucratic bottlenecks and complex accounting procedures, much more from the Indian side than the US one, have held up the Logistics Exchange Memorandum of Agreement (LEMOA) from becoming operational till now.India is also in no tearing hurry to ink the other two "foundational agreements", in addition to LEMOA, which are being pushed by the US for over 15 years now. These are the Communications Compatibility and Security Arrangement (COMCASA), earlier called the Communication Interoperability and Security Memorandum Agreement (CISMOA), and the Basic Exchange and Cooperation Agreement for Geo-Spatial Cooperation (BECA). "India is keen on further building interoperability between the two forces but it has to follow capacity-building.COMCASA and BECA will take time," said an official. Some military officers, on their part, maintain that one effective way of balancing the longterm threat from China, which has increasingly become assertive in the entire Asia-Pacific, is to militarily work closely with the US. But critics contend the "foundational pacts" will only lead to a formal military alliance with the US in the years ahead, while adversely impacting the close strategic partnership with Russia as well as needlessly antagonising China. "A pact like COMCASA also has the potential to compromise our operational security by allowing the US military to snoop on our warships and aircraft," said another officer. 
http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/defence/seven-months-on-india-us-logistics-pact-suffering-from-bottlenecks/articleshow/57728573.cms

Tillerson in his trip to the east is not stopping in Delhi, and that is a huge mistake. I am sure he is not worry about Modi and the new win for the nationalists. I think Tillerson representing the US is losing a golden opportunity to work with India from the get go, this new US administration is in fumble mood. I have to readjust this one base on the strength that nationalist India is gaining and the poor judgement of the US.
India has agreed to sign them, but negotiations haven't begun yet.
Only 10 months left in the year, looking less and less probable.
Not befoe US becomes a reliable partner again

With the election of Trump, things are way to uncertain, to deepen the US-India relations and risk antagonizing Russia and China, not knowing how things will play out under the new government.  If one agreement is signed, I guess it will be the Basic Exchange and Cooperation Agreement. Snowden disclosures in combination with Trump mean a serious risk for backdoors, if using US communication equipment.

There is one thing you want to hear from your friends and enemies "we do no trust....." that is what is here within India and China at a louder rate, the US approaching and improving Indian relations will take place and bear some major progress towards agreements in many fields, removing some of the present angst between both countries.
Good way for both US and India to antagonize China further.
The reason for my high percentage at 'No' is the new president Donald Trump.

Things are still cold, but there is some glimpse of flexibility, and the new US administration has some cabinet members with substantial interests in India. Those interests will be protected and I have the feeling that at least one will get done, as things develop will time to readjust this one towards the one only side.

Defense cooperation between India and the United States has long been bounded by New Delhi’s apprehension about Washington’s intentions and LSA, CISMOA, and BECA would signal the start of a new era, coinciding with the recently updated U.S.-India defense framework. These agreements might not be concluded during Carter’s visit to India next week, but they’ll remain at the top of his agenda and of the U.S.-India defense agenda until they’re signed—or set aside in an acknowledgment of the enduring limits to this bilateral.

Both is unlikely, the new US administration will focus in opening trade barriers, specially anything that can open doors for financial engineering. I have the feeling this kind of approach is not going to work too well with the style of negotiations that India follows.

As its taken 10 years to get agreement on what sounds like the least contentious of these 3 agreements, under a US president that is presumed to be interested in a pivot to Asia, I do not see either India or the US to be in a rush for the next two parts.

No rush on this--these papers have been languishing for many years already.  Anyway, India will want to watch the new US administration to see if they are likely to be reliable partners before signing up.  If heavy obligations such as NATO and NAFTA can be abandoned on a whim, lower-intensity agreements may be regarded as essentially meaningless.  This may be clearer by year-end,  Or not.
In response to potential Terrorist, Iranian, Pakistani, Russian and Chinese threats, both the Trump Administration and India's leadership will feel the need to strengthen their alliance.
With the senate approving India as a Key defense partner, I can only think of these agreements to be a done deal to facilitate more bilateral cooperation.
I think it's difficult for any nation to sign an information agreement with US. Not sure about the general agreement, but this my starting point.

BJP has been slowly taking India closer to US so they will try to get this closed ASAP. But with the whole country's defence establishment doubtful & untrusting of the US due to multiple historical situations where india was targetted they cannot do it instantly. So they have gone the slow way and steadily adding up. so i feel that atleast one more will be signed within the next year if not both. the unkown is the new president :) but that is for everyone.
India likes the walk the middle path and won't want to provoke either side, so they will move very slowly.
They need currency stabilization help and we will assist if they sign quickly.

Inertia suggests continuing movement towards signing.  Potential difficulties between new US regime, China, and Pakistan suggest bias towards signing.  Uncertainty re how new US administration foreign policy plus Trump related variance limits bias towards signing.
India & Soviet Union (now Russia) have a historical relationship with each other. As long as Pakistan is aligned with USA, India will not sign such defense agreement.
I put the probability of each event roughly at 30% and consider them independent. P(Non-A and Non-B)=P(Non-A).P(Non-B); P(only one)=P(A).P(Non-B)+P(Non-A).P(B); P(A and B)= P(A).P(B)
China will rattle its sabers too much for India to ignore.

Trump et al are pushing to isolate pakistan and china. It serves both purposes. Furthermore, Trump's style is to make deals and India won't have the time and patience of a nuanced philosopher like Obama. Too many forces all directed at India-USA strategic entanglement to ignore in my opinion. But the USA has such strict policies on sharing intelligence that I think CISMA is unlikely.

Impedes India's "strategic autonomy". India does not really get any substantial benefits out of the other two.
Unlikely, anytime soon.

Symbolism matters; the way the agreements were split into a triumvirate is problematic to start with and the way Modi agreed without buy in from everyone and their cousin in the legislature is too reminiscent of the high-handed approach of past rulers. Plus anything smacking of colonialism is an anathema there. Based on all this there is very little chance that even the agreement that has been approved will last unaltered.  There is a remote likelihood of one of the other agreements getting signed because Trump may have a better grasp of what's required in political maneuvering to outright corruption to get the deal done.

Default position of 'No', probability of one or the other at 25%, and probability of both somewhat correlated. I have no further information about this now than skimming the description and will adjust accordingly, as I have time to learn more.
It took ten years to get India to sign the LSA. With a new administration coming in India may move slowly as their relationship with the USA is reexamined.

Link:  http://www.defensenews.com/story/defense/international/2016/04/12/india-us-reach-agreement-logistics-boost-defense-ties/82936758/ Link: http://thediplomat.com/2016/04/lsa-cismoa-beca-and-the-future-of-the-us-india-defense-partnership/ Link: http://www.dawn.com/news/1280873 Link: http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/manohar-parrikar-signs-key-logistics-defence-pact-with-us-3004581/ While there is no indication that the two remaining agreements have been signed, and that there significant disagreement within the Indian military institutions regarding the value of these agreements (and the cost of providing the DoD with Indian military data it ostensibly does not current have), it seems that the remaining agreements will take time to complete by both states.  However, it is possible that the agreements could / could not be reached by the parties before the termination of the IFP. Probability estimate, subject to change over time = 45 on No.

If I were India, which as it happens I'm not, I would sit on these a while longer to gauge how mercurial and unreliable M. Petits-Doigts will be in adhering to agreements already signed.  On the other hand, I may sign due to the felt need to offset whatever chumminess he exhibits with Pakistan and China, despite being pretty sure he has no idea what is going on.

If after a decade of working on these issues, they haven't agreed, then they won't now.  Plus Trump is too unstable and irrational to be trustworthy.  I don't see this happening in 2017 unless there is some major outside influence, such as aggression by China or heightened aggression by Pakistan.

I have to think that if they were going to sign the remaining two agreements they would have done so already. But with US electoral change and Trump being a wild card, it is hard to see what India gains until the effects of a Trump presidency settle out. No idea how he will deal with Pakistan, or China or anyone else in the area. I think they will wait and see. But if they are all in they are all in, so if it happens at all I see it as them signing both
